item.title: Hey, ChatGPT: Where Should I Go to College?
item.description: High schoolers are turning to chatbots for help navigating the college admissions process. Does a virtual college coach know what’s best for students?
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann
item.category: National Assn for College Admission Counseling
item.media:credit: Andrew Spear for The New York Times

item.title: Getting Married in Birkenstocks
item.description: The popular sandal company is collaborating with the brand Danielle Frankel to create a collection using lustrous fabrics and materials.
item.dc:creator: Sadiba Hasan

item.title: Test Your Brain Rot: Can You Define ‘Lowkenuinely’?
item.description: This is a series about the mysteries of internet speak.
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: In Couture, Chanel Celebrates Older Women
item.description: In his first couture show, the designer Matthieu Blazy changes the rules.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Peter White/Getty Images
item.media:description: Stephanie Cavalli opens the Chanel show.

item.title: Why Celine Works
item.description: Their newish creative director Michael Rider is at the head of the pack.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Milan and Paris Men’s Fashion Week 2026: Top Street Style Looks and Runway Trends
item.description: Notable outfits, people and takeaways from the streets and runways in Milan and Paris.
item.dc:creator: Simbarashe Cha
item.media:description: A dapper customer at Bar Luce in Milan, where the fashion crowd is known to congregate after Prada’s runway shows.

item.title: After Alex Pretti, Kyle Rittenhouse Is Again a Lightning Rod Online
item.description: After the death of Alex Pretti, some people are posting about a different young man who brought a gun to a protest and the treatment he received from law enforcement agents.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Taylor Pemberton
item.media:credit: Grace Ramey/Daily News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kyle Rittenhouse has been celebrated on the right as a symbol of Second Amendment rights.

item.title: The Cult of Charvet
item.description: A collaboration with Chanel highlighted the Paris shirtmaker’s unique appeal. Six clients talk about their long relationships with the shop.
item.dc:creator: Alice Cavanagh and James Hill
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marc Beaugé’s Charvet shirts have long, narrow collars designed just for him.

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Cooler, Funnier Version of Myself’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Rama Duwaji Joins New Yorkers at an Art Party
item.description: The city’s first lady showed up for a night out with artists, writers and celebrities at the Whitney Museum’s winter fund-raiser.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vadukul and Nina Westervelt
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times

item.title: Sydney Sweeney Launches Lingerie Brand Syrn With Hollywood Sign Stunt
item.description: The actress proved, once again, she has a knack for thriving in the attention economy.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi
item.media:credit: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters
item.media:description: Sydney Sweeney, who is no stranger to controversy, pulled off a marketing stunt that could land her in hot water.

item.title: A Big Day for Thigh-High Boots on Men
item.description: Paris men’s fashion week comes to a close with Saint Laurent.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Blondet Eliot/ABACA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Something Alexander Skarsgard might have worn on his press tour for “Pillion.”

item.title: Why Do Houseguests Expect Us to Pay for Any Food During Their Visits?
item.description: A married couple is unsure how to get guests at their vacation home to pony up for groceries — ideally without being asked.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes
item.media:credit: Miguel Porlan

item.title: Being the Fun Dad Almost Destroyed My Marriage
item.description: For years, Jordan Carlos left most of the chores and child care to his wife. By the time he realized he didn’t want to be that guy anymore, it was almost too late.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Aman Sahota

item.title: How to Make and Keep Friends
item.description: Finding friendship and maintaining connections in adulthood is hard. Here’s where to start.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Jonathan Anderson Delivers a Great Dior Couture Collection
item.description: Jonathan Anderson delivers an unexpected guest — and a great collection.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Simbarashe Cha/The New York Times

item.title: A New Costes Hotel Opens in Paris
item.description: Hotel Costes defined a generation. With his first luxury hotel, a second-generation Costes looks to revolutionize how guests experience Paris. If you can get in, that is.
item.dc:creator: Tina Isaac-Goizé
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the nightclub at L’Aventure, the new Costes hotel.

item.title: Can I Wear a Sweatshirt to Work?
item.description: Trendy and expensive hoodies are everywhere, but our critic offers some words of warning before you wear one to the office.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Stephen Lam/Getty Images

item.title: These Liberals Listen to Right-Wing Podcasts to Leave Their Media Comfort Zone
item.description: To get outside their bubbles — and crib some tactics — members of a listening club are plunging themselves into a world they had once avoided.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jordan Silver and Nina Harris are the creators of Unfortunately Not a Sound Bath, a podcast listening club.

item.title: Morris Katz Is 26 and Ready to Fix the Democrats’ Strategy
item.description: Part casting director, part media guru, Morris Katz is behind the biggest Democratic campaigns this cycle.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Bernstein
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Morris Katz, 26, said his strategy was to “let Zohran cook.” But he may have his work cut out for him as he tries to elect a new slate of Democrats.

item.title: Fashion Is Exaggerating the Female Form Like Never Before. What Is Going On?
item.description: Fashion has begun exaggerating, or distorting, the female form like never before. What exactly is going on?
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: Pat Montandon, Socialite Who Sought Publicity, and Then World Peace, Dies at 96
item.description: She was known for her lavish parties and her marriage to one of the richest men in San Francisco. After he left her, she found a new purpose: visiting world leaders to plead for peace.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:credit: Bill Cunningham/The New York Times
item.media:description: Pat Montandon in 1981 with her boyfriend, James Borton, at Ronald Reagan’s inauguration.

item.title: Ava DuVernay, Ethan Hawke and Patti LuPone Honor Robert Redford at Sundance
item.description: Film lovers celebrated the festival’s final year in Park City, Utah, with a surprise performance by Ms. LuPone.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Dulany and Maggie Shannon

item.title: A Revelation in Paris
item.description: At Paris Fashion week, a stirring new discovery overshadowed all the runway theatrics.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher

item.title: Will Leaving My Terrible Job Make Me Look Flaky?
item.description: And, picking up the slack for a colleague with long Covid.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: How Weddings Are Becoming More Sensory-Friendly for the Neurodiverse
item.description: Weddings can be challenging for those with neurodivergence. As awareness grows, vendors are creating sensory-friendly solutions.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Diamond

item.title: In Search of a Platonic Co-Parent Online
item.description: Platforms that match partners in procreation are experiencing a post-pandemic uptick.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Clara Lacasse for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emma Berthou, in the striped shirt, tried for a year to have a child by insemination with a man she met on Facebook. Now she has a 16-month-old son with two friends who are a couple.

item.title: How Wide Do You Want Your Clothes?
item.description: At the shows for IM Men, Amiri, Rick Owens and Dries Van Noten, the fits varied from slim to ballooning.
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: From left, Photographs by IM Men; Daniele Oberrauch/GoRunway; Simbarashe Cha/The New York Times; Kartik Research; OWENSCORP

item.title: It Makes Sense That People See A.I. as God
item.description: A religious fervor surrounds our relationship with technology.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Bernstein

item.title: That ‘Crazy’ Compliment He Never Forgot
item.description: At a birthday party two years ago, Sarah Gall boldly told Holden Rosen Grupp that he was cute and to call her if he was ever single. Several months later, he did just that.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: A College Film Project Turned Into a Life Together
item.description: Casey DelBasso and Christopher Kelley met on the first day of college and instantly clicked, but it was almost three years before they became a couple.
item.dc:creator: Donna Kim

item.title: The ‘Invisible Strings’ That Brought Them Together
item.description: Samantha Podell and Robert Mitchell met through a dating app nearly five years ago and soon discovered they had a lot in common.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Vora

item.title: Love Found Its Pace in a New York Walking Group
item.description: Margaret Victor and Chuck Barraza met through Shorewalkers, an environmental walking group. On their first date, Ms. Victor was “really thrown” to learn that he was 16 years her senior.
item.dc:creator: Tammy LaGorce

item.title: The Kiss That Stopped Traffic
item.description: If you choose to live your life on the road, you may end up having the best kiss of your life in the middle of the street.
item.dc:creator: Marya Hornbacher
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Barbara G. Walker, Knitting Innovator, Is Dead at 95
item.description: After teaching herself to knit, she invented and cataloged stitch patterns, publishing seven foundational books that sold hundreds of thousands of copies.
item.dc:creator: Joanne Kaufman

item.title: Dior Could Use a Distillation
item.description: Jonathan Anderson came with some divine inspiration — but was it too much?
item.dc:creator: Jacob Gallagher
item.media:credit: Simbarashe Cha/The New York Times

item.title: Myths and Facts About Narcissists
item.description: Narcissism has become a catchall label for a range of frustrating behaviors. Here are some misconceptions about what it means.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron

item.title: When a Coat Becomes a Symbol of Conflict
item.description: How the choice of outerwear for Gregory Bovino, a Border Patrol official, turned into part of the deportation story.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gregory Bovino, flanked by federal agents, in Minneapolis in January.

item.title: The Exacting, Ephemeral Art of Ice Carving
item.description: A look inside a Queens studio where Buddhas, sneakers and swans are carved with reverence and the knowledge that beauty, like ice, is fleeting.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and Erin Schaff

item.title: Cyndi Lauper Cleans Out Her Closet
item.description: Fans lined up for a chance to buy a piece of the pop star’s wardrobe, even without her at the sale.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Nina Westervelt
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I love her freedom of expression, that she stands up for human rights. I love that she’s a weirdo,” said Riley Verry about Cyndi Lauper. Ms. Verry bought a handmade plastic chapeau that looked like a series of Saturn’s rings.

item.title: America Turns 250: A Guide to the Coming Festivities
item.description: Girl Scouts singing folk songs, a flag-waving party and a Times Square ball drop are among the planned Semiquincentennial celebrations.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
